byline.original: By ALISSA J. RUBIN; Sharifullah Sahak and Taimoor Shah contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan -- Boys almost always look up to their elder brothers and their friends, but what if your brother is a suicide bomber or one in training -- do you want to train, too? A new and disturbing video posted on YouTube that has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times shows a group of Afghan or Pakistani Pashtun boys role-playing the last moments in the life of a suicide bomber. Whether it is meant as a rehearsal or as a form of propaganda for the Taliban is impossible to say, but the message is clear: This is something to aspire to.
docs.abstract: Disturbing video posted on YouTube shows a group of Afghan or Pakistani Pashtun boys role-playing the last moments in the life of a suicide bomber as something to aspire to; Taliban spokesman says the insurgents did not make the video but do approve of it (M)
docs.snippet: A video on YouTube shows Afghan or Pakistani Pashtun boys role-playing the last moments in the life of a suicide bomber....

headline.main: Pashtun Boys' Video Exalts Suicide Raids

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in California acquitted a Chinese businessman on Monday of illegally exporting microwave technology to China for military purposes, while finding him guilty of making false statements to federal investigators. Qing Chang Jiang, president of EHI Group USA and Araj Electronics, both of Cupertino, Calif., was arrested by customs agents in January 2003 and charged with exporting microwave amplifiers to China without a permit. The amplifiers have applications both in the commercial sector and in the military, where they can be used in equipment for tracking missiles.
docs.snippet: The businessman was acquitted of illegally exporting microwave technology to China for military purposes but was found guilty of making false statements....

headline.main: Chinese Businessman Acquitted of Illegal High-Technology Exports

docs.abstract: The search giant is adapting its old playbook to compete in cloud computing: enlist small developers around the world and hope some of them create something huge. One hazard: Amazon and Microsoft are wise to this tactic.
